title: Charter High Ping
body: Southern California switched from frontier to charter, Ping increases from 60 to 80~100 why?

replies.body:
Your ISP (Charter) determines your network route to any server. If the route they assign you takes longer than the one that Frontier used, it will result in higher latency (ping). I'd recommend running a traceroute log to confirm where the latency starts to rise and where this may be resolved. You can do this by grabbing a network app called [**WinMTR**](http://winmtr.net/), opening the app, plugging **104.160.131.1** into the host field, then starting the trace. After 5 minutes has passed, export the results as *text* and paste them in a reply to me.

Let me know if you run into any issues.

Thanks for sending this traceroute. It reveals that your entire route to the servers is plagued with consistent *packet loss* and latency (ping) spikes of 1000ms+. All of this starts on the first hop outside of your network (**acr02crtsca-tge-0-0-0-2.crts.ca.charter.com**) and continues along the way until you reach our servers.

The solution is to reach out to your ISP's technical support team and request a tier 2 agent. Provide that agent with context on the issue you're seeing and this traceroute so they can start an investigation. Let me know if you have any questions.

Talk to charter and i feel like they are avoiding it. 

"I'm sorry sir but if there's no noticeable problems with the internet I can't do anything about the ping"

asked for the tier 2 agent, the guy just ignores it...

That sucks. :/

It's been my experience that sometimes it can take multiple calls or escalations before a solution is seen from contacting an ISP. I encourage you to persevere with this until you see a solution.
